sentenceInfoList.sentence: Á la puerta del palacio encontró Casilda á su padre, y arrodillándose á sus pies, le dijo:
sentenceInfoList.translation: At the door of the palace Casilda found her father, and kneeling at his feet, she said to him:

sentenceInfoList.sentence: En las mazmorras gime muchedumbre de cautivos.
sentenceInfoList.translation: In the dungeons a crowd of captives moans.

sentenceInfoList.sentence: Quítales sus cadenas, ábreles las puertas de su prisión y déjalos tornar á tierra de nazarenos, donde lloran por ellos padres, hermanos, esposas, amadas.
sentenceInfoList.translation: Take off their chains, open the doors of their prison and let them return to the land of the Nazarenes, where parents, brothers, wives, loved ones cry for them.

sentenceInfoList.sentence: El moro bendijo á su hija en el fondo de su corazón, porque era bueno y amaba á Casilda como á la niña de sus ojos.
sentenceInfoList.translation: The Moor blessed his daughter from the bottom of his heart, because he was good and loved Casilda like the apple of his eye.

sentenceInfoList.sentence: El pobre moro no tenía más hija que aquélla.
sentenceInfoList.translation: The poor Moor had no other daughter than that one.

sentenceInfoList.sentence: El pobre moro amaba á Casilda porque era su hija, y porque era además la viva imagen de la dulce esposa cuya pérdida lloraba hacía un año.
sentenceInfoList.translation: The poor Moor loved Casilda because she was his daughter, and because she was also the living image of the sweet wife whose loss he had mourned a year ago.

sentenceInfoList.sentence: Pero el moro, antes que padre, era musulmán y rey, y se creía obligado á castigar la audacia de su hija.
sentenceInfoList.translation: But the Moor, before being a father, was a Muslim and a king, and he believed he was obliged to punish his daughter's audacity.

sentenceInfoList.sentence: Porque compadecer á los cautivos cristianos y pedir su libertad, era un crimen que el Profeta mandaba castigar con la muerte.
sentenceInfoList.translation: Because pitying Christian captives and asking for their freedom was a crime that the Prophet ordered to be punished with death.

sentenceInfoList.sentence: Por eso ocultó la complacencia de su alma, y dijo á Casilda con airado semblante y voz amenazadora:
sentenceInfoList.translation: That is why he hid the complacency of his soul, and said to Casilda with an angry countenance and threatening voice:

sentenceInfoList.sentence: ¡Tu lengua será cortada y tu cuerpo arrojado á las llamas, que tal pena merece quien aboga por los nazarenos!
sentenceInfoList.translation: Your tongue will be cut out and your body will be thrown into the flames, such a penalty is deserved by anyone who advocates for the Nazarenes!

sentenceInfoList.sentence: É iba á llamar á sus verdugos para entregarles su hija.
sentenceInfoList.translation: He was going to call his executioners to hand over his daughter to them.

sentenceInfoList.sentence: Pero Casilda cayó de nuevo á sus pies, demandándole perdón en memoria de su madre.
sentenceInfoList.translation: But Casilda fell again at his feet, asking for forgiveness in memory of her mother.

sentenceInfoList.sentence: El pobre moro sintió sus ojos arrasados en lágrimas, y estrechó á su hija contra su corazón, y la perdonó, diciendo:
sentenceInfoList.translation: The poor Moor felt his eyes filled with tears, and he hugged his daughter to his heart, and forgave her, saying:

sentenceInfoList.sentence: —Guárdate, hija mía, de pedir otra vez por los cristianos, y aún de compadecerlos, porque entonces no habrá misericordia para ti; que el santo Profeta ha escrito: «Exterminado será el creyente que no extermine á los infieles.»
sentenceInfoList.translation: —Beware, my daughter, of asking again for Christians, and even of pitying them, because then there will be no mercy for you; that the holy Prophet has written: "The believer who does not exterminate the infidels will be exterminated."

longDef: impersonal neuter pronoun (accusative) in certain colloquial phrases: it, this
La sabe toda.  ― He/she knows everything (it all)
¡Dónde la viste!  ― Where have you seen this!
No te la creo.  ― I don't believe you.

puerta.shortDef: door (portal of entry into a building)
longDef: (Noun) door (portal of entry into a building)
(Contraction) of the, from the (+ a masculine noun in singular).
María y Gertrudis se escondieron cerca de las flores, y los chicos las encontraron a las chicas. ― Mary and Gertrude hid themselves near the flowers, and the boys found the girls.
Su casa es grande. - His house is big.
Su madre es muy simpática. - Her mother is very nice.
¿Cómo está su familia? - How is your family?
¿Dónde está su coche? - Where is your car?

Es, pues, de saber que este sobredicho hidalgo, los ratos que estaba ocioso —que eran los más del año—, se daba a leer libros de caballerías, con tanta afición y gusto, que olvidó casi de todo punto el ejercicio de la caza y aun la administración de su hacienda; y llegó a tanto su curiosidad y desatino en esto, que vendió muchas hanegas de tierra de sembradura para comprar libros de caballerías en que leer, y, así, llevó a su casa todos cuantos pudo haber dellos. ― You must know, then, that the above-named gentleman whenever he was at leisure (which was mostly all the year round) gave himself up to reading books of chivalry with such ardour and avidity that he almost entirely neglected the pursuit of his field-sports, and even the management of his property; and to such a pitch did his eagerness and infatuation go that he sold many an acre of tillageland to buy books of chivalry to read, and brought home as many of them as he could get.

se.shortDef: oneself, himself, herself, itself, yourself; each other; one another
longDef: (Pronoun) third person (also used for usted and ustedes) reflexive direct or indirect object oneself, himself, herself, itself, yourself; each other; one another
Juan se lava. ― Juan washes himself.
Juan se lava la cara. ― Juan washes his own face. (literally, "Juan to himself washes the face.")
Juan y María se aman. ― Juan and María love each other.
(Pronoun) used to convey the meaning of the English passive voice in the third person and with usted and ustedes
¿Cómo se llama? ― What is your name? (literally, "How do you call yourself?")
Se dice que... ― It is said that... (literally, "It says itself that...")
Aquí se habla español ― Spanish is spoken here / They speak Spanish here. (literally, "One speaks Spanish here, Spanish speaks itself here.")
(Noun) English or American foot (a unit of length equal to 30.48 cm)
first-person singular preterite indicative of piar

pi.shortDef: pi; the Greek letter Π, π

le.shortDef: to him, to her, to you
longDef: To her, for her (dative form of ella)
To him, for him (dative form of él)
To you, for you (dative form of usted, ello, lo)
Es un mentiroso. Nunca dice la verdad. ― He's a liar. He never tells the truth.

¿Qué te dijeron? ― What did they tell you?
1615, Miguel de Cervantes, "Capítulo XXXII", in El ingenioso hidalgo Don Quijote de la Mancha, Segunda parte:

Digo, señor don Quijote -dijo la duquesa-, que en todo cuanto vuestra merced dice va con pie de plomo, y, como suele decirse, con la sonda en la mano; y que yo desde aquí adelante creeré  […]  que hay Dulcinea en el Toboso,  […]  merecedora que un tal caballero como es el señor don Quijote la sirva; que es lo más que puedo ni sé encarecer. ― "I say, Sir Don Quixote," said the duchess, "that in all your mercy says, he goes with leaden feet, and as the saying goes, with sounding plummet in hand; and that I henceforth will believe,  […]  that there is a Dulcinea in El Toboso,  […]  deserving of such a knight as Sir Don Quixote in her service, which is the highest praise that I can give her."

se\u00f1or.shortDef: mister, sir, lord (title conferred on a married or older male)
longDef: (Noun) mister, sir, lord (title conferred on a married or older male)
dar un señor golpe ― Give a good big whack
(Can we add an example for this sense?)
Estoy en casa. ― I'm at home.
Estoy sentado en la computadora. ― I'm sitting at the computer.
en esta página ― on this page
en la caja en la mesa ― in the box on the table

Synonym: calabozo
2023 February 10, Iker Seisdedos, "Relatos de la peor mazmorra de Nicaragua: "Nos engrillaban para dormir o cuando nos llevaban al ‘túnel’. Allí te esperaban los golpes"", in El País‎[1]:

El Infiernillo carga la fama de ser la peor mazmorra de Managua. Allí, en esa cárcel de máxima seguridad, Solís, estudiante de Derecho, pasó tres años en régimen de aislamiento, en un "camarote sin luz solar, con la puerta siempre sellada". ― (please add an English translation of this quotation)

Synonyms: gentío, multitud, turba
2022 December 8, Juan Diego Quesada, Inés Santaeulalia, "Los 180 minutos que hicieron temblar Perú", in El País‎[1], retrieved 2022-12-08:

Comenzó su presidencia aclamado en las plazas por las muchedumbres como el hombre humilde que venía a representar a los que nunca habían gobernado en Perú. ― (please add an English translation of this quotation)
(Preposition) of; 's; used after the thing owned and before the owner
Constitución española de 1812 ― Spanish constitution of 1812
la cola del perro ― the dog’s tail
(Preposition) from (with the source or provenance of or at)
Soy de España. ― I’m from Spain.
The name of the Latin-script letter D.
first-person singular present indicative of cautivar
(Verb) (transitive) to remove, to take away, to take down, to take off, to pull off, to pull out, to clear, to clear away, to strip, to strip away

cadena.shortDef: chain (series of interconnected rings or links usually made of metal)
longDef: (Noun) chain (series of interconnected rings or links usually made of metal)
(Noun) necklace (article of jewelry that is worn around the neck)
(Verb) (transitive, intransitive, reflexive) to open, open up
Por favor abre la ventana, Jorge. ― Please open the window, George.
Abro la cerradura. ― I unlock the lock.

prisi\u00f3n.shortDef: prison (a place or institution of confinement, especially of long-term confinement for those convicted of serious crimes or otherwise considered undesirable by the government)
longDef: (Noun) prison (a place or institution of confinement, especially of long-term confinement for those convicted of serious crimes or otherwise considered undesirable by the government)
Synonyms: cárcel, penitenciaría, penal, CERESO, (Mexico) Cereso

dejar.shortDef: to leave, abandon, to let, allow
longDef: Dejé la cerveza arriba. ― I left the beer upstairs.
(Verb) (transitive) to leave, to keep (to allow to continue)
Me gusta dejar la luz encendida. ― I like to keep/leave the light on.
Supongo que podríamos dejar el restaurante abierto un poco más. ― I suppose we could keep the restaurant open a little bit longer.
Accusative form of ellos or ustedes
Plural masculine or neuter pronoun, e.g. los que no hablan, "those who do not speak"
(Verb) (intransitive) to come back; to go back

Synonyms: regresar, retornar, volver
1877, Benito Pérez Galdós, Gloria:
Como además vieron al doctor Sedeño abstraído en la lectura de los periódicos políticos, tornaron al jardín. ― (please add an English translation of this quotation)

tierra.shortDef: land, ground (the part of Earth which is not covered by oceans or other bodies of water)
longDef: (Noun) (geography) land, ground (the part of Earth which is not covered by oceans or other bodies of water)
(Noun) (geology) earth, soil (the unconsolidated mineral or organic material on the immediate surface of the earth)
Alternative letter-case form of Tierra ("Earth") (our planet, third from the Sun)
(Noun) someone from Dos Hermanas, a city in Seville
from Dos Hermanas, a city in Seville
El lugar donde estamos es secreto. ― The place where we are is secret.
(in indirect questions) where, in what place
Deja los libros donde quieras. ― Leave the books where you want.
Estamos donde la plaza mayor. ― We're around by the main square.
Cenamos donde Daniel. ― We're having dinner (round) at Daniel's place.
El bebé lloró toda la noche. ― The baby cried all night.
Lo hice por ti. - I did it for you.
Escrito por Juan. - Written by Juan.
Entra por la puerta principal. - Enter through the main door.
Yo tengo tantos hermanos / Que no los puedo contar / Y una novia muy hermosa / Que se llama Libertad ― (please add an English translation of this quotation)
first-person singular present indicative of hermanar
(Verb) to love, have great affection for, care about
(Article) feminine singular definite article used before nouns which start with a stressed /a/:
el alma, las almas ― the soul, the souls
el hacha, las hachas ― the axe, the axes
(Noun) (colloquial) a Muslim or Arab, particularly Muslims in the southern Philippines
first-person singular present indicative of morar
(Verb) to reside, to dwell, to abide

era.shortDef: era, age, past tense of ser

longDef: Yo soy de los Estados Unidos. ― I am from the United States.

Errar es humano. ― To err is human.
2007, El Sueño de Morfeo, Nada es Suficiente:

¿Qué voy a ser si te he dado lo que soy? ― What am I going to be if I've given you what I am?
2007, El Sueño de Morfeo, Para Toda la Vida:
Si fueras una gota de agua, nadie volvería a tener sed ― If you were a drop of water, no one would thirst again
(Verb) to be (in the passive voice sense)
La guitarra fue tocada. ― The guitar was played.
Que tengas una buena noche. ― Have a good night.
Que tengas un buen viaje. ― Have a good trip.
Synonyms: vale, de acuerdo, está bien
(used at the start of a phrase) well; a short pause in a sentence
Bueno, pues, mira. ― Well, then, look.

como.shortDef: as (introducing a basis of comparison or equality)
longDef: (Conjunction) as (introducing a basis of comparison or equality)
¿Tienes tanta hambre como yo? ― Are you as hungry as I am?
Como nunca vio mi mensaje, vamos sin ella. ― Since she never saw my message, we're going without her.
as (to such an extent or degree)
No es tan alta como nosotras. ― She's not as tall as us.
Hemos esperado como media hora. ― We've waited like half an hour.
as (in the manner or role specified)
Mis ahijados me ven como un tío. ― My godchildren see me as an uncle.
Synonyms: por ejemplo, como por ejemplo
Algunos países de Asia, como Laos y Vietnam... ― Some countries in Asia, such as Laos and Vietnam...
first-person singular present indicative of comer
Dora tiene (los) ojos azules. ― Dora has blue eyes.

Mi pobre vecino siempre está llorando. ― My poor neighbor is always crying.
2013, El sueño el Morfeo, Vuelve (a donde has venido):

El pasado ya es pasado, no tienes que pedir perdón. Solo déjanos tranquilos a mí y a mi pobre corazón. ― The past is the past, you don't have to ask forgiveness. Just leave us alone, me and my poor heart.
(Adjective) (after the noun) poor (lacking money, resources, etc.)
Se relajan las familias ricas en casas lujosas y las familias pobres tiran en chozas desmoronadas. ― The rich families relax in luxurious houses and the poor families get by in dilapidated huts.
Ella tiene seis hermanos. ― She has six brothers.
Tengo una pluma. ― I have a pen.
(Verb) (transitive) to have, possess, to be (a condition or quality)
Usted tiene suerte. ― You are lucky. (literally, "You have luck.")
¿Quién tiene razón? ― Who is right? (literally, "Who has reason?")
Teresa es más lista que su hermano. ― Teresa is more clever than her brother.

Hay más de cien personas aquí. ― There are more than a hundred people here.
1605, Miguel de Cervantes, "Capítulo I", in El ingenioso hidalgo Don Quijote de la Mancha, Primera parte:

Una olla de algo más vaca que carnero, salpicón las más noches, duelos y quebrantos los sábados, lantejas los viernes, algún palomino de añadidura los domingos, consumían las tres partes de su hacienda ― A pot of stew of rather more beef than mutton, a salad on most nights, scraps on Saturdays, lentils on Fridays, and a pigeon or so extra on Sundays, made away with three-quarters of his income.
(Adverb) (with definite article) most; -est (used to make superlatives)
Teresa es la más inteligente de la clase. ― Teresa is the most intelligent in her class.
la cosa más grande ― the biggest thing
uno más uno es igual a dos ― one plus one is equal to two
Él dice que está triste. ― He says that he is sad.
Llego más tarde que tú. ― I am arriving later than you.
la estrella que está en la película ― the star who is in the movie
la mujer con la que yo hablé ― the woman with whom I spoke

aqu\u00e9lla.shortDef: feminine form of aquél that one (far from speaker and listener)
longDef: feminine form of aquél that one (far from speaker and listener)

adem\u00e1s.shortDef: in addition, moreover, furthermore, further, also, additionally
longDef: (Adverb) in addition, moreover, furthermore, further, also, additionally
(Adverb) as well, also, not to mention (when in the middle of a sentence or toward the end)
second-person singular voseo present indicative of ademar
first-person singular present indicative of vivir
first-person singular present indicative of vivar
(Verb) (intransitive) to make a living, to live on
Vive de migas, nada más. ― He lives on crumbs, nothing more.
sweet (having a pleasant taste, especially induced by sugar)

Antonym: salado
2004, Akira Yamaoka, translated by from English, Tender Sugar:
Me salva la dulce azúcar, es la habitación que me confina ― (please add an English translation of this quotation)
No sé que hago. ― I don't know what I'm doing.
Prefiero no hacerlo ― I prefer not to do it.
Empecemos a hacer el pastel. ― Let's start making the cake.
Le gustaba hacer poemas placenteros. ― She liked to make pleasant poems.
Nos quedan muchos haceres. ― We have a lot of tasks left.
¡Mira al cielo, hay un águila! - Look at the sky, there's an eagle!
¡Manos arriba, tengo un arma! - Hands up, I have a gun!
el año que viene ― next year
el año vigente ― the current year
va para un año que no te veo ― it's been a year since I saw you
con los años me cuesta cada vez más estar feliz ― over the years I find it harder and harder to be happy
dentro de un par de años ― in a couple of years' time
el mejor año de mi vida ― the best year of my life
todos los años es igual ― it's the same thing year on year
en sus años mozo ― in her childhood years
Tengo veinte años. ― I'm twenty [years old].
Depende de los años que tenga. ― It depends how old it is.
Mi casa es pequeña, pero cómoda. ― My house is small, but comfortable.
(Conjunction) well well; so; well (used for emphasis)

antes.shortDef: earlier, before, sooner, previously, formerly, beforehand (at an earlier time)
longDef: (Adverb) earlier, before, sooner, previously, formerly, beforehand (at an earlier time)
Antonyms: después, luego, posteriormente, a posteriori
Nos conocimos antes, ¿te acuerdas? ― We met before, remember?
La embajadora llegó antes de lo esperado. ― The ambassador arrived sooner than expected
Quería que lo supieras cuanto antes. ― I wanted to let you know  as soon as possible.
Ven a mi casa lo antes posible. ― Come over to my place as soon as possible.
before (earlier than) (triggers the subjunctive in subordinate clauses)
antes de que pudiera responder ― before I could reply
Antes de ver el documental, no sabíamos nada del tema. ― Before watching the documentary, we didn't know anything about the issue.
(Verb) (transitive) to think, to believe, to reckon, to be of the opinion
Creo que es mejor así. ― I believe it's better this way.
(Verb) to force, to compel, to make (someone do something)
Por favor no me obligues a hacer esto. ― Please don't make me do this.
(Verb) to oblige, to obligate, to bind

La Carta de las Naciones Unidas obliga a todos los miembros de la organización a respetar el principio de la no discriminación. ― The Charter of the United Nations binds all the members of the organization to respect the principle of non-discrimination.
(Verb) to punish, to castigate (to cause to suffer for crime or misconduct)
(Verb) to ground, gate (to punish, especially a child or teenager, by forcing them to stay at home and/or give up certain privileges)
(Verb) (transitive, reflexive) to feel sorry (for); to pity
first-person singular present indicative of cristianar
Él le pidió agua al camarero. ― He asked the waiter for water.
¿Puede pedirle el dinero? ― Can you ask her for the money?
(Verb) to request someone else to do something

Pido que ustedes estén ahí a la una. ― I ask that you be there at one o'clock.
2016 November, "La raza de gatos más cariñosa", in Frontera.info‎[1]:
Si no les das el cariño suficiente acudirán a pedírtelo por lo que necesitan dueños que puedan prestarles la suficiente atención. ― (please add an English translation of this quotation)
me mandó a disparar ― He ordered me to fire
Yo cuento con ustedes. ― I count on you.
(Noun) (often capitalized) death (the personification of death as a hooded figure)
Synonyms: Parca, ángel de la muerte
Eso es un perro. - That is a dog.
Eso es lo que quiero. - That is what I want.
Synonyms: rostro, faz, cara, apariencia, aspecto

Dulce y lejana voz por mí vertida.Dulce y lejana voz por mí gustada.Lejana y dulce voz amortecida. ― Sweet and faraway voice flowing for me.Sweet and faraway voice tasted by me.Faraway and sweet voice muffled softly.
first-person singular present indicative of falsar
(Adjective) (said of a writing style) choppy, disconnected
a coffee or espresso with a small amount of warm milk added
(Verb) to cut off, cut out, cut through, cut down, cut up, to nip

cuerpo.shortDef: body (the physical structure of a human or animal)
longDef: (Noun) body (the physical structure of a human or animal)
(Verb) (transitive) to throw, to hurl, to toss, to fling (cause an object to move rapidly through the air)
(Verb) (transitive) to emit (to send out or give off)
Te estuve llamando a voces. ― I was summoning you by voice.

Me llamó con la mano para que me acercase. ― [He] summoned me with [his] hand in order to bring me near.
to call (on the telephone)
Te llaman desde París. ― They are calling you from Paris.
Que me llamen a las siete. ― May they call me at seven o'clock.

Ha llamado a Maribel. ― [He] has called Maribel.
to knock (on a door)

Entren sin llamar. ― Enter without knocking.
to ring (a doorbell)
¿Cómo van a llamar al niño? ― How are they going to refer to the child?
Eso yo lo llamo un auténtico robo. ― I refer to that as an authentic robbery.
La llamó de todo. ― [He] referred to her about everything.
No hay tal cosa como los monstruos. ― There's no such thing as monsters.

inflection of penar:
third-person singular present indicative
second-person singular imperative
Mereces mucho más que esto. ― You deserve a lot more than this.
(Verb) (Argentina, vulgar, slang, dated) to have sex, used especially when talking about a nubile girl
Ella está en edad de merecer. ― She is of the age of deserving.
La mujer con quien se casó ― The woman whom he married
La persona a quien yo amo ― The person whom I love
(Verb) (intransitive) to go (away from speaker and listener)
Nos gusta ir al cine. ― We like to go to the movies.
(Verb) (intransitive) to come (towards or with the listener)
Quiero ir contigo. ― I want to come with you.
Iré a tu casa. ― I'll come to your house.

verdugo.shortDef: executioner, hangman (official person who carries out the capital punishment of a criminal)
longDef: (Noun) executioner, hangman (official person who carries out the capital punishment of a criminal)

Synonym: oficial
2021 August 26, Eva Saiz, quoting Juan Manuel Guijo, "Los desenterradores de la memoria en la fosa de Pico Reja", in El País‎[1]:
"La verdad de los verdugos no se reproduce en los archivos. Es la tierra la que habla", afirma Guijo. ― (please add an English translation of this quotation)
La niña compró un regalo de navidad para su abuela.  ― The girl bought a Christmas gift for her grandmother.
Ahora me gustaría hacer un truco de magia para ustedes.  ― I'd now like to perform a magic trick for you all.
(Preposition) to, in order to, so, for (expressing the intended purpose of an action)
Estudio cada noche sin descanso para conseguir un trabajo decente al fin de todo esto.  ― I study every night tirelessly so that I get a decent job at the end of all this.
Voy a salir temprano para evitar el tráfico.  ― I am going to leave early to avoid traffic.

inflection of parar:
third-person singular present indicative
second-person singular imperative

inflection of parir:
first/third-person singular present subjunctive
third-person singular imperative
(Verb) (transitive) to deliver, to hand over, to hand off
(Verb) (intransitive, reflexive) to fall (to move to a lower position due to gravity)
(Verb) (intransitive) to fall (to come down, to drop, to descend)
La lluvia cae más fuerte que antes. ― The rain is falling heavier than before.

memoria.shortDef: memory (the ability of the brain to record information)
longDef: (Noun) memory (the ability of the brain to record information)
Por primera vez en mi vida, yo sentí verdadera paz. ― For the first time in my life, I felt true peace.
Ella sintió a su corazón latir rápidamente. ― She felt her heart beating rapidly.
Siento que deberías que estar aquí conmigo. ― I feel that you are supposed to be here with me.

Un día, como Gloria, viéndole sumergido en hondos comentarios sobre la unidad religiosa impuesta a los Estados después de la unidad política, le dijese que en su sentir los reyes de España habían hecho mal en arrojar del país a los judíos y a los moros, Lantigua abrió mucho los ojos, y después de contemplarla en silencio mientras duró el breve paroxismo de su asombro, le dijo:―Eso es saber más de la cuenta. ¿Qué entiendes tú de eso? Vete a tocar el piano. ― (please add an English translation of this quotation)
(Verb) (transitive) to lay waste to, to rampage, to devastate
la lucha contra el prejuicio ― the fight against prejudice
perdona por no contestarte, tío ― sorry I didn't get back to you, man
(Verb) (transitive) to save (to store for future use)
(Verb) (computing) to save (to write a file to disk or other storage medium)
guardar un archivo ― to save a file

m\u00eda.shortDef: a regiment of 100 soldiers in the Spanish protectorate of Morocco
longDef: (Noun) (Morocco, military, historical) a regiment of 100 soldiers in the Spanish protectorate of Morocco

otra.shortDef: feminine of otro; another, another one
longDef: feminine of otro; another, another one
Lo hizo dos veces. ― He did it twice.
cada vez que te veo ― every time that I see you

Aún no ha llegado. ― He has not arrived yet.
1917, Rubén Darío, "A Roosevelt", in Cantos de vida y esperanza:

Eres los Estados Unidos,  eres el futuro invasor  de la América ingenua que tiene sangre indígena,  que aún reza a Jesucristo y aún habla en español. ― You are the United States  you are the future invader  of the naive America that has indigenous blood  that still prays to Jesus Christ and that still speaks Spanish

entonces.shortDef: then, next, thereupon, at that time, at that point
longDef: (Conjunction) then, next, thereupon, at that time, at that point
Desde entonces, siempre he tenido cuidado. ― Since then I've always been careful.
Entonces, el ladrón se fue. ― After that, the thief left.
Estaba lloviendo antes, entonces de seguro viniste con paraguas, ¿no?. ― It was raining before, so you certainly came in with an umbrella, didn't you?.

haber.shortDef: to have (to do something, auxiliary verb)
longDef: (Verb) (auxiliary verb taking past participle to build various perfect tenses) to have
He trabajado muy duro durante este mes. ― I have worked very hard during this month.
Mi hermanito me pidió más chocolate, pero ya le había dado demasiado. ― My little brother asked me for more chocolate, but I had already given him too much.

ti.shortDef: you, thee (declined form of tú used as the object of a preposition)
longDef: (Pronoun) you, thee (declined form of tú used as the object of a preposition)
(Noun) a typescript, embossed or pressed manuscript or document
having stains or scratches resembling writing
(Verb) (transitive, intransitive) to write (to form letters, words or symbols on a surface in order to communicate)
Escribe todas sus ideas en un cuaderno. ― She writes all her ideas in a notebook.
¿Cómo se escribe tu apellido? ― How do you spell your last name?
(Verb) (transitive) to write (to be the author of (a book, article, poem, etc.))
Cervantes escribió el Quijote a comienzos del siglo XVII. ― Cervantes wrote Don Quijote at the beginning of the 17th century.

title: Á la puerta del palacio encontró Casilda á su padre, y arrodillándose á sus pies, le dijo:
